evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and documented in the historical data for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period.

defeaters: Evidence showing clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
Statements indicating the headset operator and wingman provided timely warnings
Evidence that the visual signals were sufficient and understood

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The tug instructor's statement (H8) directly indicates a lack of effective communication and warning from the wingman and headset operator about the impending collision, evidencing a communication breakdown. The trainee's decision to stop and hand over control (H2) and the instructor's actions (H3) show coordination attempts but insufficient to prevent the incident (H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct transcripts or recordings of communications; reliance on post-event statements introduces potential bias or incomplete information.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the event.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates a mechanical or control failure occurred; the incident involved pushback procedure and human factors without mention of mechanical/control failure (H1-H9).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct or indirect evidence about mechanical/control failure is provided.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, including timing, crew roles, and operational context during hist_t2_interim.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed missing, unclear, or inadequate TRP markings or environmental conditions affecting visibility or recognition of the TRP on 12-25.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any environmental or marking deficiency was present or observable on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe.

defeaters: If there was evidence that the pushback procedure was followed correctly or no deviation occurred
If the incident was not documented or observable in the specified timeframe or aircraft

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope, reflecting relevant operational characteristics.

assumptions: The TRP and clearance details provided are representative of the key operational characteristics for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in this scope
The described communication and training methods reflect relevant operational features
defeaters: Additional evidence showing that the procedural deviation was due to factors unrelated to key operational characteristics
Evidence that the TRP or clearance standards differ significantly for this aircraft or location
Information indicating that the communication methods or training were not representative of standard operational features

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.

assumptions: The described communications and actions represent the full scope of the pushback event
No other external factors influenced the deviation beyond those described
defeaters: If new evidence showed effective communication or warnings were given and ignored
If procedural standards were different or better defined
If the trainee or instructor had prior incidents indicating negligence

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the incident
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft control systems
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates any mechanical or control failure; the incident appears related to tug driver actions and communication issues.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence from Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim, with no contradictory data undermining this root cause.

assumptions: Absence of warnings implies communication breakdown
Training and communication setup should have prevented the incident if effective
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication warnings were given before the collision
If contradictory data indicated other causes for the incident

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication channels existed (H1, H3) and that the trainee was trained and aware of procedures (H9), yet no warnings were given before the collision (H8), indicating a breakdown in communication/coordination resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit contradictory evidence or detailed communication logs

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality reports of communication equipment and confirm no outages during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not engaged in conflicting tasks that prevented communication
children_spec.test_procedure: Review task assignments and workload logs to determine if any crew member was unavailable due to other duties

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is resistant to common defeaters and alternative explanations.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure is inferred from the aircraft moving beyond TRP without command
No direct mechanical diagnostics are provided
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but ignored
If mechanical failure was directly observed or diagnosed
If alternative explanations like human error were ruled out

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that the pushback continued beyond the TRP despite the tug instructor's visual signals being insufficient and no warnings from other personnel (H8, H4). The trainee was qualified and had prior uneventful experience (H9), suggesting alternative explanations like human error or communication failure are plausible, reducing confidence in the mechanical/control failure being resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence of mechanical/control failure and reliance on indirect observations

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential counterarguments or conditions that could negate its presence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_t2_interim on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking is intended to prevent the aircraft from moving beyond a safe point
The lack of warning from wingman or headset operator contributed to the incident
defeaters: If there was evidence that the visual signals were adequate and consistently effective
If the headset operator or wingman had provided timely warnings
If the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous under all conditions

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 defines the TRP marking and clearance, H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, and H8 highlights the insufficiency of visual signals to stop the tug driver, supporting the robustness of the environmental/marking deficiency identification.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on visibility conditions or alternative signaling methods effectiveness

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the operation, or if communication attempts failed due to physical absence.

node.statement: Crew members were not engaged in conflicting tasks that prevented communication

assumptions: Presence of headset operator and wingman implies potential for communication unless engaged in conflicting tasks
defeaters: Evidence that crew members were engaged in other conflicting tasks preventing communication
Direct statements confirming crew engagement in conflicting tasks

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H8 indicates no warnings were given by wingman or headset operator, suggesting possible lack of engagement in communication; H3 shows headset operator and wingman were physically present but does not confirm active communication or conflicting tasks.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity about the level of engagement of crew members in other tasks; no explicit evidence about conflicting tasks preventing communication

children_spec.statement: Relevant environmental information was not available to the flight crew during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check flight data recordings, cockpit displays, and crew reports for presence or absence of environmental information at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: Markings or signage related to the environment were missing or not visible to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the physical environment and review maintenance and inspection records for presence and visibility of required markings or signage

children_spec.statement: Environmental or marking information was available but not accessible or interpretable by the crew
